questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of oral ulcers, large areas of denuded skin, and flaccid blisters. What is the first-line investigation for this condition?

choices.text: Tzanck smear from the floor of blister

questions.solution:
This clinical picture is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. The first-line investigation is Tzanck smear.

It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.

Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image above is alopecia areata. Classically, it causes fine stippled pitting of the nails.

It is a chronic inflammatory disease which causes non-scarring patches of hair loss, especially in genetically predisposed.

The most characteristic lesion is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia, which has short extractable broken hairs called as exclamation mark hair. However, there is always sparing of white hairs in the region affected.

Other options :

Subungal oil drop sign is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discolouration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

 

Leukonychia striata are lines that extend across the nail and lie parallel to lunula. They are seen in Hypoalbuminemic states such as nephrotic syndrome .

 

Nail Pterygium is a wing-shaped deformity of nail due to a central fibrotic band which divides the nail into two parts in the proximal.

  • Dorsal pterygium is seen in lichen planus.
  • Ventral pterygium is seen in trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus, familial subungual pterygium, and infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of the following intensely itchy rash over his elbows, knees, buttocks, and upper back. He has been having persistent watery loose stools for the past 3 months and reports feeling more tired than usual. A complete blood count shows microcytic, hypochromic anemia. It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease. It is also associated with HLA DQ2/DQ8/B8. Deposition of IgA antitransglutaminase antibodies in the dermal papillae results in subepidermal blisters and vesicles.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is Nikolsky's sign seen?
  1. Pemphigus vulgaris
  2. Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  3. Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  4. Pemphigus foliaceus
  5. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
questions.solution:
Nikolsky's sign is positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Nikolsky's sign refers to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis by applying firm tangential sliding pressure, thereby producing an erosion. It is seen in conditions that produce intraepidermal blisters. Hence it is negative in subepidermal bullous conditions like bullous pemphigoid and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

Pseudo-Nikolsky's sign refers to epidermal separation as a result of epidermal necrosis, not acantholysis.

It is seen in

  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk of a child with positive Darier's sign, which is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa:

It is the commonest type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. 

The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20-40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features:

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific for mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • Psoralen + ultraviolet light A (PUVA) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called as café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size from 1 to 2 mm to greater than 20 cm in greatest diameter. They may appear at birth or at the first decade.

They may present on any body parts, but most commonly involves the trunk and the extremities. Darier's sign is not seen in CALMs.

They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1, NF2), McCune-Albright syndrome, and tuberous sclerosis.

Image below shows café‐au‐lait spots.

Option B: Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a benign proliferative disorder of histiocytes occurring in early infancy and childhood.

It presents as reddish yellow maculo-papular lesions which may evolve into yellow brown patches/plaques with surface telangiectasis.

They may be single or multiple. Single lesions are the most common. Lesions occur most commonly on the face, head and neck, followed by trunk and extremities.

Darier's sign is positive in juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Image below shows a yellow papule in the right inner arm of a child suggestive of juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It present as tense blisters and vesicles, urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels,” "cluster of jewels," or “string of pearls” formation, although this sign may also be seen in bullous pemphigoid. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

The image below shows linear IgA dermatosis at various sites.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought by her parents with itchy blisters on her face and buttocks that developed quite suddenly. History revealed an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis 2 weeks ago that was treated with penicillin. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealed IgA deposition, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing linear deposition of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic for linear IgA disease or chronic bullous disorder of childhood or IgA pemphigoid.

It is the most common immunobullous disease in infants and children. It may occur <5 years or at 60-65 years of age. It occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and can be triggered by drugs like vancomycin, penicillin, and NSAIDs. The main target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2. 

The classic triad of clinical features is:

  1. Tense blisters
  2. Vesicles
  3. Annular erythema

Onset is abrupt in children with involvement of the perioral and perianal regions. In adults, the extensor areas and trunk are affected. The blisters are arranged in an annular pattern. This is called the crown of jewels or string of pearls appearance, as shown below.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as?
questions.solution:
Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as a preservative to inhibit bacterial growth. It is permitted to be used up to the level of 100 ppm.

Several cases of allergic contact dermatitis due to MI were reported due to its presence in wet wipes, hair cosmetics, facial cosmetics, deodorants, and sunscreens.

Furthermore, cases of airborne exposure to MI causing severe airborne and generalized dermatitis from recently painted walls and even from toilet cleaners have been described.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is this finding characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a confluent macular violaceous erythema called the V sign seen in patients of dermatomyositis.

It is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle and usually presents initially with a facial rash, especially around eyelids, which can be pruritic and sore. Myositis symptoms are usually weakness and fatigue especially while climbing stairs, raising arms, and standing from sitting due to proximal muscle weakness.

The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

The clinical signs seen in dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron papules - flat-topped lichenoid eruption on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joint
  • Shawl sign or V sign - fixed erythematous macular erythema
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

questions.text: Which of the following dermatological conditions is the likely cause of the characteristic nail finding shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate, which is seen in lichen planus. Thinning of the nail plate is the most frequent nail change seen in lichen planus.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease:

  • Viruses like hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), and varicella zoster virus
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa is a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with lesions over his elbow as shown in the given image. Similar lesions are noted over the dorsum of the penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an aggregate of pinhead-sized papules over the elbow of a child, which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

Lichen nitidus is a rare variant of lichen planus, where both are histologically similar in early lesions. It is mostly seen in children and young adults. Lesions of lichen nitidus are typically described as a minute pinpoint to pinhead-size, flat or dome-shaped papules with a shiny surface. They are most commonly found over the forearm, dorsum of the penis, abdomen, chest, and buttocks. They are usually asymptomatic, but can also present with severe pruritus. Koebner phenomenon, if present, is a hallmark of the disease. Nail pitting or rough nails with increased linear striations and longitudinal ridges may be present.

 

Lichen nitidus is found to be associated with Crohn's disease, Down's syndrome, congenital megacolon, and Niemann-Pick disease.

There are several histological characteristics of lichen nitidus. The distinguishing feature of lichen nitidus is a well-circumscribed granulomatous infiltration in the papillary dermis that is surrounded by extensions of epidermal ridges and composed of lymphocytes, macrophages, Langerhans giant cells, and multinucleated epithelioid histiocytes. Usually spanning 4 to 5 dermal papillae in the dermis, this clearly defined inflammatory infiltration has a "ball-in-clutch" appearance.

Other options:

Option A: Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by Sarcoptes scabiei. It presents as vesicles, burrows, and nodules in locations such as interdigital spaces, forearms, breasts, and genitalia.

Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a condition that typically affects children and adolescents who have a great immune sensitivity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is believed to be the outcome of the immune system's reaction to the hemorrhagic dissemination of a tuberculous focus that underlies it. The lesions often consist of small, asymptomatic follicular papules that range in color from skin tone to erythema. are typically over the abdomen, chest, back, or proximal limbs.

Option D: Miliaria rubra is caused due to eccrine sweat gland obstruction which results in leakage of sweat into the epidermis. Common lesions form on the body where the skin rubs against clothing and in the flexures. The lesions are essentially little erythematous papules. Lesions commonly develop on the obstructed skin of the neck, groins, and axillae in infants, though they can also occur elsewhere.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense bullae associated with pruritus. The lesions began first as erythema and urticaria. Physical examination shows tense bullae on the trunk and thigh region. Direct immunofluorescence done on skin biopsy tissue is as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Immunofluorescence shows linear deposits of IgG and C3
Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosome antigens
Acantholysis is uniformly seen on histology

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with a continuous linear immunofluorescence pattern shown in the image is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk that do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. Since these antigens are not present in mucosa, mucosal involvement is not frequently seen as in pemphigus vulgaris. It is present in only 10% of cases.

The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. These blisters are tense and do not rupture easily and Eosinophils are present just below the basal cell layer. Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 deposits in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

Image: Direct immunofluorescence shows continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction

Image (above) shows the fishnet pattern of immunofluorescence in pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture shows a neonate encased in a shiny, parchment-like membrane (collodion baby) suggestive of a disorder belonging to the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is not a part of this disease spectrum. It does not present at birth and is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused due to a mutation in the filaggrin gene (FLG). It develops in the first few months of life. Patients exhibit accentuated palmar and plantar creases and have dry scaly skin. The scales appear light grey and cover the extensor surfaces of the limbs and the trunk. It usually spares the groin and larger flexures. Immunohistochemistry reveals an absent or markedly reduced filaggrin signal.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum includes the following:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self- improving congenital ichthyosis (SICI)
  • Transient manifestations, such as collodion baby.

questions.text: Which of the following is best suited for the management of genital warts in a pregnant lady?
questions.solution:
Cryotherapy is considered relatively safe in pregnancy, while fluorouracil, podophyllin, and podophyllotoxin are contraindicated.

Cryotherapy treatment is physician-administered. Dimethyl ether spray, carbon dioxide snow, and liquid nitrogen all produce cold thermal damage to the skin. Liquid nitrogen produces the coldest freeze and is commonly used in practice. It is applied using a cotton wool bud or a cryospray until a rim of iced tissue (seen as a white discoloration) develops around the wart. The freeze is maintained for 5–30 seconds depending on the size and site of the wart. Scarring is unlikely with freezing times under 30 seconds. The main disadvantage of freezing is pain.

Genital warts

Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. They are most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

questions.text: A patient with vaginal discharge has the following finding on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding of trichomoniasis. It results from microscopic, punctate hemorrhages of the cervix.

It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis and is one of the most common causes of vaginal discharge. It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4–21 days.

In females, it characteristically causes a copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge with pH > 4.5, along with vaginal soreness and urinary frequency. Males can be asymptomatic or develop non-specific urethritis.

Diagnosis in females is usually easily confirmed by the presence of motile organisms on a wet film. Culture in Feinberg–Whittington medium is the most reliable method but is not routinely done.

Standard treatment is metronidazole 2g PO single dose. Regardless of treatment given, patients should avoid sexual contact for 7 days since the last antibiotic dose.

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic man presents with complaints of pain and swelling over his left middle finger, which appears as below. The digital pressure test is positive. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a positive digital pressure test and the image showing erythema and swelling around the nail folds is suggestive of acute paronychia with abscess. Abscess in paronychia requires immediate incision and drainage.

Paronychia refers to an infection of the proximal, lateral nail folds. It results from the disruption of the protective barrier between the nail and the nail fold, introducing pathogens and predisposing the area to infection. Paronychia is more common in women than in men. It can be acute if it lasts less than six weeks or chronic if it lasts for more than six weeks.

In addition to infectious causes, papulosquamous disorders like psoriasis and pemphigus also can cause paronychia.

Certain factors that predispose to paronychia include

  • Certain occupations like dishwasher, bartender, housekeeper
  • Certain medications like retinoids, protease inhibitors
  • Immunosuppressive states like diabetes, HIV, malignancy

Paronychia is diagnosed based on clinical presentation. Clinical features vary with respect to the presentation.

Acute paronychia:

  • Erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold
  • Area of fluctuance if an abscess is present - positive digital pressure test

A digital pressure test is used to assess if an abscess is present or not. Pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the involved digit. A larger than expected area of blanching will be visible at the paronychia if an abscess is present and drainage will be needed.

The image below shows acute paronychia of a fingernail.

Chronic paronychia:

  • Nail fold may be red, swollen or boggy
  • Nail plate may be thickened and discolored
  • Retraction of the proximal nail fold
  • Nail dystrophy
  • Loss of the cuticle
  • Fluctuance is rare on digital pressure test

Management involves:

  • Non-pharmacological measures like:
    • Patients should keep their hands dry and warm
    • Wear gloves for any recurrent contact with water, chemicals, and irritants
    • Avoid trauma to the hands as much as possible
    • Avoid nail-biting or manicuring nail folds until complete recovery
    • Warm soaks using antiseptics or antibiotic solutions for 10 to 15 minutes, multiple times a day.
  • Antibiotic coverage depends on the type of paronychia.
    • Acute paronychia: Since acute paronychias are mostly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, adequate coverage is required in the form of:
      • Topical antibiotics: Triple antibiotic ointment, bacitracin, or mupirocin
      • Oral antibiotics:
        • Dicloxacillin 250 mg four times a day
        • Cephalexin 500 mg three to four times a day
      • If suspecting MRSA:
        • Clindamycin 300 to 450 mg four times a day
        • Doxycycline 100 mg twice a day
    • Anaerobic coverage requires the addition of clindamycin or amoxicillin-clavulanate, in cases of suspected oral inoculation.
    • Chronic paronychia: Topical and systemic antifungal agents such as itraconazole and terbinafine are used to cover Candida species.
    • Topical tacrolimus ointment is effective in case of allergic and atopic contact dermatitis causing chronic paronychia
  • Presence of abscess warrants immediate incision and drainage under local/digital block. Partial or complete nail plate removal may be needed.
  • Surgical management of chronic paronychia involves procedures like:
    • Eponychial marsupialization: A crescent-shaped incision parallel to the distal edge of eponychium, exteriorizes the infected and obstructed nail matrix and allows its drainage.
    • En-bloc excision of the proximal nail fold
    • Swiss roll technique: Nail fold is elevated proximally over a non-adherent dressing, rolled up, and secured with the application of sutures and dressing. After 48 hours, if the wound is clean, the sutures are removed and the nail fold is brought to the original position by secondary intention. This exposure of the nail bed allows the drainage of any residual infection.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25-year-old man who came to a primary health centre 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy.   • Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units + tab. Azithromycin 1 gm single dose

questions.text:
Match the following clinical images with the corresponding diagnoses.
  1. Nevus of Ito
  2. Congenital melanocytic nevus
  3. Nevus of Ota
  4. Becker nevus
questions.solution:
Option B has the correctly matched set of images and diagnoses.

1 Nevus of Ito
2 Congenital melanocytic nevus
3 Nevus of Ota
4 Becker nevus

Image 1- shows a unilateral blue-greyish hyperpigmented macule on the shoulder, which is suggestive of nevus of Ito. It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is distinguished from the nevus of Ota by its location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves. 

Image 2 shows a dark blackish pigmented lesion over the back of an infant, which is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. Congenital melanocytic nevi are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth. Lesions are dark at birth and are usually palpable with increased surface markings. It has a slightly higher predisposition in females.

Image 3 shows bluish-brown pigmentation around the eye. This is nevus of Ota. It is a dermal melanocytosis that mainly affects the sclera and skin around the eyes. They are generally distributed along with the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is commonly seen in females. 

Image 4 shows a large, pigmented hairy patch on the shoulder, which is suggestive of Becker nevus. Becker nevus is an epidermal melanocytic nevus. It is classically seen as a hyperpigmented, brownish patch over the scapular area on the back, shoulders, outer arms, and chest. It is usually associated with hypertrichosis and sometimes with acne. It is more common among males. It has an onset around adolescence, when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy presents with hypotonia, seizures, and failure to thrive.  The mother reports that his hair started to appear short, lusterless, and thin when he was 2-months-old. A trichogram of his scalp hair is as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or trichopoliodystrophy or steely hair disease.

Pili torti refers to hair showing 180-degree twists under the microscope. Scalp and eyebrow hair appear short, sparse, lustreless, tangled, and depigmented. Hair changes can be the first sign of disease at 1–2 months of age.

It is an X‐linked recessive disorder. At 2–3 months of age, children with Menke's disease present with: 

  • Loss of developmental milestones
  • Hypotonia
  • Seizures
  • Failure to thrive
  • Cherubic appearance - depressed nasal bridge, pudgy cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip, and doughy skin.

Option A: In kwashiorkor, hair develops a lustreless, red‐brown color that may show alternation with more normal color; this so‐called ‘flag sign’ corresponds to alternating periods of significant undernutrition and improved nutrition.

Option B: Selenium deficiency presents as brittle hair and may be associated with exfoliative dermatitis on the scalp.

Option D: In zinc deficiency, hair is dry and brittle, and large areas of alopecia may arise.

Note :
Defect in ATP7A gene causes Menkes disease, X-linked recessive disorder whereas, defect in ATP7B gene causes Wilson's disease, Autosomal recessive disorder.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

  • Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury
  • Verrucous growth
  • Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

 

  Chromoblastomycosis Sporotrichosis
Cause Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii
Presentation Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics
Histology Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies Asteroid bodies

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A  wool farmer presents with a hemorrhagic lesion on his left index finger for 3 days. On examination, he is febrile and lymphadenopathy is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing small, red hemorrhagic pustules with the given scenario is suggestive of orf or ecthyma contagiosum.

It is caused by the parapox virus. The commonly affected sites are hands and forearms. Lymphadenitis, lymphangitis, and fever are often present. 

It presents with a single lesion—a small, firm, red, or reddish-blue papule that develops after 5–6 days at the site of contact with an infected animal (mostly sheep and goats) and enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule. The epidermis of an orf lesion shows ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

Treatment is usually not necessary, and the lesions heal after 3-6 weeks.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with painless growths over the skin of vulval region since 3 months, as seen in the image. The probable diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is condylomata acuminata or venereal warts. It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by human papilloma virus 6 or 11.

Verrucous, exophytic cauliflower-like growths can be seen over the skin of the vulval region, perineum, and perianal region which are usually non-tender.

Treatment -

  • Local application of Podophyllin 25% in alcohol or Podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin for 6 hour daily,
  • Podofilox 0.5% solution
  • Trichloroacetic acid and bichloroacetic acid applied serially
  • Intralesional injection of Interferon

Vaccination - Cervarix at 0, 1 and 6 months; Gardasil at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Genital herpes - It presents with painful blisters/genital ulcers. It is caused by herpes simplex virus 2.

Gonococcal vulvovaginitis - It is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient usually presents with swollen, painful external genitalia and erythema around external urinary meatus, along with foul smelling vaginal discharge.

Condyloma lata - These are infectious plaques that are broad, pink or gray-white present in warm, moist body areas. It is hallmark of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests would you use to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo in a patient?
questions.solution:
Diascopy is a test that helps to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo.

Nevus anemicus is secondary to a localized area of vasoconstriction, and diascopy of the adjacent skin reveals a color identical to that of the ‘depigmented’ area, since other pigments are unaltered. In vitiligo, the lesion appears paler, since there is a loss of melanin.

Diascopy is a clinical maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. In this procedure, a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic is pressed onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on diascopy, known as ‘apple jelly’ nodules. They are seen in all 3 of sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • Differentiation between nevus anemicus and nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevus: Application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation between erythema (vasodilation) and purpura (extravasated blood): Erythema blanches on compression of vessels, while purpura and petechiae do not blanch on compression.

Wood's lamp examination can also be used to distinguish between vitiligo and nevus anemicus.

In vitiligo, the depigmented areas appear milky white, due to a loss of melanin, while in nevus anemicus, the pallor completely disappears, since it is secondary to localized vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman in the first trimester of pregnancy presents to your clinic with hair loss. She gives a history of typhoid fever 3 months ago. What is the pattern of hair loss seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium. It is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen (proliferative) phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting > 6 months. Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are:

  • Thyroid disorders (Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism)
  • Severe iron deficiency anemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth. The circulating placental estrogen during pregnancy prolongs anagen phase. After delivery, the estrogen withdrawal pushes all the hair simultaneously into catagen and then telogen phase.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient from Bihar comes with complaints of hypopigmented macules over the trunk and face. The nerves and sensations are found to be normal and there is no visible scaling. The patient gives a history of prolonged fever 2 years back for which he was treated. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis. The drug of choice for this condition is miltefosine. 

Approach to the case: 

The patient hails from a kala-azar endemic zone—Bihar. The rash appears 1-2 years after a history of prolonged fever, which suggests visceral leishmaniasis. There are 2 other differentials—leprosy and tinea versicolor. 

  • The presence of hypopigmented macules over the trunk and face, suggests a differential of leprosy, but the nerves and sensations are normal, hence ruling it out.
  • There is no scaling visible in the lesions, ruling out tinea versicolor. 

In kala-azar, after a variable period of years or months, diffuse nodulation begins to develop in these macules. The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously. As it may persist for up to 20 years, these patients may act as a chronic reservoir of infection.

The image below shows post-kala-azar cutaneous leishmaniasis. 

Although studies say that miltefosine is the drug of choice for the treatment of PKDL, according to the Kala-azar Elimination Program, the preferred order of drugs to treat PKDL:

 (i) Liposomal amphotericin B > (ii) Miltefosine > (iii) Amphotericin B deoxycholate

Since miltefosine is strongly contraindicated in pregnancy, it is not preferred as the first choice for wide-scale elimination.

questions.text: A female came with complaints of bone and joint pain. NSAIDs were prescribed. After a few days, she presents again complaining of itchy vesiculobullous lesions healing to give a brownish discoloration over the face (upper lip area), as shown in the image. A fixed drug eruption is suspected. All of the following measures would be valid steps to treat her, except __________.
questions.solution:
Management of fixed drug eruption (FDE) involves stopping the offending drug and symptomatic treatment with systemic antihistamines and topical/systemic steroids. Cyclosporine has no role in the management of FDE. Acute-onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE. The time between drug intake and skin symptoms was, on average, two days which is consistent with the time of onset in the question stem.

Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location. But new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug. FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Paracetamol/ NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID-induced FDE - lips and genitals
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/ sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

A strong differential diagnosis is post-chikungunya hyperpigmentation reaction of the centro-facial face seen on the nose and cheeks (so-called “chik sign”). However, this is not the answer because the pigmentary changes develop after the fever subsides and may persist for about 3 to 6 months. The question stem describes the onset of pigmentary changes after a few days. Also, these patients do not have any preceding erythema or eruption over the affected areas during the acute febrile phase.

questions.text: The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of ________.
questions.solution:
The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of psoriasis.

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis), and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

questions.text: You have ordered a patch test for an 8-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis. When should you ask him to return for the final reading of the patch test?
questions.solution:
In patch testing, the final reading done for confirmation is done after 72-96 hours.

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning).

  • 48 hours: Patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation. 

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg of prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was referred to the dermatology outpatient department with painful, erythematous nodular lesions on the extensor surface of the upper limbs. He also complains of fever and malaise. He had completed treatment for leprosy six months ago. This condition is caused by __________.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of painful, erythematous nodules over the limbs (extensor surface) in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type II lepra reaction. It is caused by type III hypersensitivity reaction which is immune-complex mediated.

Type II lepra reactions (ENL) are mainly seen in multibacillary disease; LL (50%) > BL (15%). They can occur before, during, or after treatment, and are commonly recurrent. These reactions are caused by immune complexes (type III hypersensitivity). ENL presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. Systemic manifestations like fever, malaise, anorexia, neuritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, etc. can also be seen. Treatment of type II lepra reactions includes high-dose steroids, thalidomide (drug of choice in young men with severe ENL), and clofazimine.

Type I lepra reaction, on the other hand, is caused by type IV hypersensitivity reaction, i.e. cell-mediated immune inflammation within existing skin lesions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male HIV patient came with a sharp, severe, constant, burning pain in the right chest. On examination, the lesion is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing confluent, red, pustular, painful lesions in a single dermatome is highly suggestive of herpes zoster infection. 

Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia most commonly affecting thoracic dermatomes. An earlier primary infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain in the affected area. It may also be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dermatome. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and the nasopharynx.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Other options: 

Option B: Irritant contact dermatitis is the cutaneous response to the physical/ toxic effects of a wide range of environmental exposures. The main clinical features are usually dryness or chapping. The lesions could commonly develop into patchy or diffuse erythema with scaling and fissuring.

Option C: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction with itchy, erythematous papules and papulovesicles that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. 

Option D: Herpes simplex lesions are thin-walled vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers that heal without scarring. This commonly affects face-orolabial herpes, genitals, and fingers- herpetic whitlow.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: There is perifollicular hyperkeratosis and keratotic papules
It is associated with liver cirrhosis and alcohol abuse
It can be seen in patients after bariatric surgery
It is predominantly associated with a deficiency of vitamin D

questions.solution:
The above image shows phrynoderma or toad skin. All the statements except statement 4 are true. Phrynoderma is predominantly associated with a deficiency of Vitamin A.  

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency, it is also seen in other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition.

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. 

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 
For children above 8 years and adults - 100,000 units daily for 3 days, followed by 50,000 units daily for 2 weeks and then 10,000 units daily for 2 months till liver stores are replenished.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is candidal intertrigo.

It is a candidal infection of opposing skin surfaces, which presents as erythema with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold. When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.

As the condition progresses, it spreads beyond the area of contact, usually developing the typical features of candidosis with a fringed, irregular edge and subcorneal pustules rupturing to give tiny erosions, and then further peeling of the stratum corneum.

Treatment:

Topical antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows plaque psoriasis of the dorsum of the hand, and isomorphic or Koebner phenomenon is associated with the condition.

Option B: Meyerson phenomenon refers to the formation of an eczematous ring around a melanocytic nevus.

Option C: Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints.

Option D: Nikolsky sign refers to easy peeling of skin on applying tangential pressure over a bony prominence and is classically seen in pemphigus and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: A commercial sex worker presents with an indurated, painless ulcer over her vulva. Which of the following organisms is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
A painless and indurated ulcer in a sex worker is characteristic of primary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.  

Treponema is a corkscrew organism. The coils are very close and regular with around 7 to 8 coils per diameter of a red blood corpuscle. It contains a flagellum and its graceful movements are pathognomonic. It rotates along its long axis and appears to screw slowly forwards and backwards.

Option A: Listeria is a rod-shaped bacterium.

Option C: Helicobacter pylori is spiral or rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacterium. It​​ has two to seven unipolar flagella. It is smaller than spirochetes.

Option D: Leptospira is also spiral and highly motile. They can be distinguished from other spirochetes by their unique question mark hook at the end of the bacterium. It is more tightly wound than Treponema with 18 or more coils per cell.

questions.text: A dermatology resident performing Wood's lamp examination on a patient notes a milky-white fluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ivory or milky-white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is seen in vitiligo.

In vitiligo, there is less or no epidermal melanin in the affected patches. As the normal function of melanin is to absorb light, the vitiligo-affected patches cannot block the light emitted from deeper layers of the skin. They appear as bluish, milky, or ivory white patches with sharp margins. Woods lamp is hence helpful in the diagnosis of vitiligo, especially in fair-skinned people in whom lesions may not be obvious to the naked eye.

The following image shows milky-white fluorescence under a Wood's lamp. 

World Vitiligo Day on June 25th raises awareness about combating stigma associated with the condition, promotes acceptance, and encourages solidarity among those living with vitiligo. The day highlights the need for better treatment options, funding for research, and support services.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with pruritic, hypopigmented macules on his chest and abdomen, as shown in the image given below. On examination using Wood's lamp, pale yellow fluorescence was noted. Which of the following is used as the first-line drug in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches, is suggestive of tinea verisolor/pityriasis versicolor. Topical terbinafine is a first-line drug that can be used to treat this condition.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. It is caused by a fungus named Malassezia, a part of the normal skin microbiota, which are lipid-dependent for survival.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. 

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to "spaghetti and meatballs" or "bananas and grapes." 

Pale yellow fluorescence is seen in Wood’s lamp examination is characteristic of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here, the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole or selenium shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Itraconazole tablets are useful as second-line management. Relapses are very common.

questions.text: Which of the following are included in malpighian layer of the epidermis?
questions.solution: The malpighian layer of the epidermis includes both stratum basale and stratum spinosum as a unit. It is named after Marcello Malpighi.

questions.text: In which of the following dermatological conditions is the following manifestation the first to appear?
questions.solution:
• The first and most common manifestation of pityriasis rosea is the herald patch, which tends to be larger than the patches that form later and is usually situated in the thigh, trunk, upper arm, or neck regions.
  • It is a sharply defined, erythematous, round or oval plaque and is soon covered by fine scales.
  • This condition is self-limiting and is considered to be viral in origin.
  • It is known to occur commonly in the age groups between 10 to 35 years.
  • In later parts of the disease, a Christmas tree pattern of patches tends to occur over the skin.
  • Drugs like metronidazole, terbinafine, and clonidine are also known to cause pityriasis rosea-like eruptions.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is evident from the histological section of the skin shown below?
questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of nucleated cells in the stratum corneum, which indicates parakeratosis. Note that normally, the cells of stratum corneum are devoid of nucleus.

  • Parakeratosis is defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within the horny cell layer or stratum corneum.
  • It represents a disorder of keratinization, and is usually associated with an absence or reduction in thickness of the granular cell layer.
  • The histological feature of parakeratosis is commonly seen in many different forms of inflammatory dermatosis, and is closely associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.

Parakeratosis is commonly seen in

  • Psoriasis
  • Subacute eczematous reactions
  • Pityriasis lichenoides
  • Actinic keratoses
  • Bowen disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with mildly pruritic plaques in the left axilla for 2 weeks. Wood’s lamp examination showed coral-red fluorescence. What is the first-line therapeutic agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image along with coral-red fluorescence under Wood’s lamp is suggestive of erythrasma. Treatment of erythrasma is by using topical clotrimazole and miconazole for two weeks.

For more extensive lesions, erythromycin can be administered. Relapse can occur. In such cases, long-term topical povidone-iodine application with drying agents can be used. Photodynamic therapy can also be attempted. 

Erythrasma is a mild, chronic, superficial infection of the skin. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It affects the axillae, groins, toe webs, inter-gluteal and submammary regions. Lesions may be symptomless or show mild discomfort and itching.

The lesions may be of irregular shape with sharp margins. They may start as smooth, red patches and then become brown. The lesions are more likely to be pruritic in tropical regions and may be asymptomatic in temperate climate. 

The image below shows erythrasma in the axilla of a patient.

Coral‐red fluorescence with Wood’s light is due to coproporphyrin III and suggests erythrasma. The fluorescence may persist after the eradication of the disease. 

 

Note:

Aluminium chloride antiperspirant is used in trichomycosis axillaris, caused by Corynebacterium tenuis. It is a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of an adherent granular nodule which can be yellow, black, or red in color, on the hair shaft.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient came with complaints of non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of his head. Histological examination shows loss of hair with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting a young adult presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histology showing perifollicular hemorrhage is suggestive of trichotillomania (trichotillosis). 

Trichotillomania has to be differentiated from alopecia areata (Option A). Trichotillomania presents with incomplete hair loss within a patch with varying lengths of hair whereas alopecia areata shows smooth hairless patch with sparing of white hairs. Regular pitting of nails and exclamation mark hairs are seen in alopecia areata. When the diagnosis is uncertain, a scalp biopsy can be done. Perifollicular hemorrhage is characteristic of trichotillomania while peribulbar lymphocytic infiltrate is diagnostic of alopecia areata. 

Trichotillomania is classified under obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. It is characterized by recurrent body-focused repetitive behavior (hair pulling) and repeated attempts to decrease or stop the behavior. It is commonly seen in females. The hair loss is commonly seen over the vertex but can involve eyelashes, eyebrows, and beard.

The most effective treatment for trichotillosis is habit-reversal training (HRT).

Other options:

Option B: Telogen effluvium is diffuse hair loss resulting in non-scarring alopecia due to loss of telogen hairs due to fever, pregnancy, hypothyroidism or anemia.

Option C: Tinea infection shows patchy hair loss, resulting in non-scarring/scarring alopecia. Easy pluckability, broken hairs and wood's lamp positivity are features.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who is a known diabetic with a body mass index of 32 presents to the outpatient department with a skin condition around the neck, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It does not regress and is irreversible
It is more common in patients with darker skin.
The most common association is obesity.

questions.solution:
The given image of a obese, diabetic woman with a skin lesion around the neck shows acanthosis nigricans (AN). The false statement regarding this condition is that it does not regress and is irreversible.

The skin condition is characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. More common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance is the most common association with AN, and it can regress with weight loss. It is more common in patients with darker skins. 

Other conditions associated with AN:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • HAIR-AN syndrome
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

Familial AN is rare and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait.

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae called papillomatosis. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or in melanin production. 

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with: 

  • First line: Topical retinoids act by reducing hyperkeratosis.
  • Second line: Topical keratolytics like salicylic acid are used.
  • Third line: Oral isotretinoin is used for extensive cases.

questions.text: The mother of a 10-year-old boy brings him to the dermatologist for skin problems. She reports that whenever he wears tight clothing or when something brushes against his skin, his skin appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is this phenomenon seen in?
questions.solution:
The given image showing white lines that developed in response to light pressure on the skin is suggestive of white dermographism. It is pronounced in atopic dermatitis.

It is due to an abnormal vascular response, where capillary vasoconstriction occurs in response to light stroking of the skin. While it can occur normally, it is more pronounced in patients with eczema. Tight clothing is a common triggering stimulus. It causes white lines in areas where pressure has been applied, as shown below.

Note: Black dermographism is characterized by skin discoloration after pressure from a metallic object.

The FDA recently approved crisaborole, a phosphodiesterase-4-inhibitor, for topical use against mild to moderate atopic dermatitis in children ≥3 months of age.

questions.text: An infant is brought with the following lesion on the scalp. What is the likely diagnosis?

The above image shows cup‐shaped crusts/scutula around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus.

Ectothrix is a mild inflammatory type in which dull grey-coated broken hairs are seen.

Endothrix is a non-inflammatory type in which black dots form around swollen hair shafts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with skin fragility. On examination, he is noted to have erosions, bullae, and scarring over the extensor aspects of his elbows, hands, and knees. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy is given below. Presence of antibodies against which of the following is diagnostic of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing linear IgG deposits in a u-serrated pattern on direct immunofluorescence microscopy are suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA), in which autoantibodies are formed against collagen VII.

It is an acquired autoimmune disorder, presenting in adults between 44-54 years. It has a chronic, relapsing course. Two main clinical forms can be differentiated:

  • Classical mechanobullous - Skin fragility, erosions, blisters, crusts, and scars on trauma‐prone areas like hands, knuckles, elbows, knees, toes.
  • Inflammatory - Resembles other pemphigoid diseases such as bullous pemphigoid. Associated with inflammatory infiltrate in the dermis.

questions.text:
A patient presents with erythematous streak-like lesions on the trunk, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely etiology for his presenting complaints?

IKBKG - Inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa B kinase regulatory subunit gamma

NEMO - Nuclear factor-kappa B essential modulator

choices.text: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO

questions.solution:
The image in the clinical scenario above shows flagellate erythema. It is seen as a side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy. 

Flagellate erythema is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

Other options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin causes hyperpigmentation. Although erythematous streaks may occur at the site of infusion, generalized flagellate erythema is usually not seen. Cardiotoxicity is the most significant side effect of doxorubicin chemotherapy.

Option C: Burrowing of hookworm larvae in the skin causes a creeping eruption characterized by linear twisting and winding lesions mainly on the feet and hands as shown in the image given below.

Option D: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO is responsible for incontinentia pigmenti. It follows 4 stages of cutaneous lesions—erythematous vesicular rash, verrucous lesions, hyperpigmented whorls, and atrophic streaks. Lesions are seen along the lines of Blaschko. 

The image given below shows the hyperpigmented whorl stage (stage 3).

questions.text: What is the pathological basis for the given skin finding?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

 

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

questions.text:
Match the causative organism for the lesions given below.

A. Pox virus

B. Herpes simplex virus

C. Human papilloma virus

D. Human herpes virus 7
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Image 1 shows herpetic whitlow caused by herpes simplex virus.

It is often contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus; it is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions.

On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Image 2 shows verruca vulgaris or common wart caused by human papilloma virus 2 (HPV-2) but is also closely related to types 27 and 57 as well as types 1 and 4.

  • Common warts are usually asymptomatic.
  • These present as firm papules with a rough horny surface.
  • These are most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers, and, in children on the knees, but may occur anywhere on the skin.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed: new lesions along the sites of trauma.
  • Products containing salicylic acid with or without lactic acid are effective patient-applied treatments. Cryotherapy can also be effectively used for periungual warts.
  • Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic feature of koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis. (image given below)

Image 3 shows a herald patch, which is covered by fine scales. It is seen in pityriasis rosea, most commonly caused by human herpes virus-7.

  • Pityriasis rosea is an acute self‐limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults and characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms.
  • HHV‐7 is detected slightly more frequently than HHV‐6, but often both viruses are found.
  • The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch, which is larger and more conspicuous than the lesions of the later eruption and is usually situated on the thigh or upper arm, trunk, or neck and covered by fine scales.
  • After an interval, which is usually between 5 and 15 days, the general eruption begins to appear in crops and consists of discrete oval lesions,
    dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery‐grey scales.
  • The center tends to clear and assumes a wrinkled, atrophic appearance and a tawny color, with a marginal collarette of scale attached peripherally, with the free edge of the scale internally called a hanging curtain sign.
  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of cleavage parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.
  • The common asymptomatic and self‐limiting cases require no treatment.

Image 4 shows small pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center—lesions of molluscum contagiosum caused by pox virus. 

  • The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.
  • The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.
  • In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).
  • PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen - new lesions develop along line of trauma.
  • There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.
  • Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, or curettage and expression

Image: Keratinocytes of stratum malpighii become enlarged and acquire eosinophilic inclusion bodies—Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies that contain virus particles.
